_header: By true record of the Doctor Bede
_description: John Lydgate, Verses on Cambridge — fourteen rhyme royal stanzas

CULMm135.First Lines:
By trew recorde of the Doctor Bedethat some tyme wrotte so mikle
                    with his hand…
CULMm135.Last Lines:
…Five hundreth yere thirtie & eke nyneIn this matter ye
                    gett no more of meFor which by recorde all clarks seyne the sameOf heresie Cambridge bare never blame
CULMm135.Note:
Written by post-medieval hand (eighteenth-century, Thomas
                    Baker).
CULMm135.Editions:
Stubbs,  Charles W. 
             The Story of Cambridge.
         London: J. M. Dent & Co., 1905: 2-3.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS
         o.s. 192 (1934); repr. 1961: 652-5.

BLHar367.First Lines:
By trewe recorde of the doctor Bedethat some tyme wrotte so myckle
                    with his hande…
BLHar367.Last Lines: …for which By recorde all Clerkes seyne the sameof heresie Cambridge bare never blame
BLHar367.Note:
Written by the hand of John Stow, on a separate leaf tipped into the
                    volume, once folded across the middle, with verso blank except
                    scribbles.
